natural problem: Suppose that $$\begin{array}{@{}c@{\;}c@{}c@{}c} && &P_b \\ & \times & & P_b \\ \cline{2-4} & & Q & P_b, \\ \end{array} $$where $P$, $Q$, and $b$ represent three distinct digits 1-9. If $Q=\frac{P}{2}$, and $P$ is two less than $b$, what is the value of the digit $P$?
natural solution: We can rewrite $QP_b$ as $Q\cdot b+P$, or $\left(\frac{P}{2}\right)b+P$ in base 10.

So, we have $P\cdot P=\left(\frac{P}{2}\right)b+P$. The value of $P$ is two less than $b$, so we substitute $(P+2)$ for $b$ and get \begin{align} P^2&=\frac{P(P+2)}{2}+P\quad\Rightarrow\\ P^2&=\frac{P^2+2P+2P}{2}\quad\Rightarrow\\
2P^2&=P^2+4P\quad\Rightarrow\\ P^2-4P&=0\quad\Rightarrow\\ P(P-4)&=0. \end{align}That means $P=0$ or $P=4$, but the problem says $P$ is a digit from 1 to 9.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P Q b :: nat
assumes h0 : "distinct [P, Q, b]"
and h1 : "P \<in> {1..9}"
and h2 : "Q \<in> {1..9}"
and h3 : "b \<in> {1..9}"
and h4 : "Q = P div 2"
and h5 : "P = b - 2"
shows  "P = 4"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Suppose that $$\begin{array}{@{}c@{\;}c@{}c@{}c} && &P_b \\ & \times & & P_b \\ \cline{2-4} & & Q & P_b, \\ \end{array} $$where $P$, $Q$, and $b$ represent three distinct digits 1-9. If $Q=\frac{P}{2}$, and $P$ is two less than $b$, what is the value of the digit $P$? The final Answer is 4
 ### Proof
 We can rewrite $QP_b$ as $Q\cdot b+P$, or $\left(\frac{P}{2}\right)b+P$ in base 10.
 So, we have $P\cdot P=\left(\frac{P}{2}\right)b+P$. The value of $P$ is two less than $b$, so we substitute $(P+2)$ for $b$ and get \begin{align} P^2&=\frac{P(P+2)}{2}+P\quad\Rightarrow\\ P^2&=\frac{P^2+2P+2P}{2}\quad\Rightarrow\\
 2P^2&=P^2+4P\quad\Rightarrow\\ P^2-4P&=0\quad\Rightarrow\\ P(P-4)&=0. \end{align}That means $P=0$ or $P=4$, but the problem says $P$ is a digit from 1 to 9.
 So, the value of $P$ is $\boxed{4}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes P Q b :: nat
assumes h0 : "distinct [P, Q, b]"
and h1 : "P \<in> {1..9}"
and h2 : "Q \<in> {1..9}"
and h3 : "b \<in> {1..9}"
and h4 : "Q = P div 2"
and h5 : "P = b - 2"
shows  "P = 4"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
